messageBody:
Your question is quite general so I give you my general answer:

In general I think you should avoid mocking external API:s wrap the API in a
service and mock that
is my general advice. Something like:

public interface Queue {
void sendMessage(Message msg);
}

public class JmsQueue implements Queue {
<jms-stuff goes here>
}

If the "wrapper" (JmsQueue) remains the only un-unittested part of your
system it is good enough to catch
those problems the in your automated integration/acceptance tests. You can
also test the wrapper in isolation with JMS mocked out.
Then JMS is only visible in those tetsts and those tests can focus solely on
the aspects of the wrapper while
tests for your other classes can use a mocked Queue.

The same goes if you are listening to a JMS queue, keep the JMS stuff out of
your business logic (at the edges of your system) and
I beleive you will have an easier time with testing.

I hope this helps.
/Joakim Ohlrogge
